meta.title: What's Your Child's Calm-Down Style?
meta.description: Discover which calming strategies actually work for your child. This evidence-based assessment maps your kid's natural regulation style across movement, sensory, and verbal channels.
meta.intro: Not every calm-down trick works for every kid. Some need to move, some need to squeeze something, and some need to talk it through. This quiz figures out which toolkit your child actually needs.
meta.subject: your child
meta.shareCta: Which calm-down strategies actually work for your kid? Find out.

questions.text: When your child is upset, what does their body do?
questions.subtext: Think about the last few meltdowns — feet, hands, whole body.

options.text: They get physically restless — running, jumping, flailing, can't sit still
Some fidgeting or stomping, but they mostly stay in place
They go still — freeze, curl up, or get very quiet

questions.text: How does your child respond to physical comfort when they're dysregulated?
questions.subtext: Tight hugs, blankets, holding a stuffed animal, squeezing something.

options.text: They actively seek it out — grabs a blanket, asks for a hug, clutches a lovey
They'll accept it if offered, but don't seek it on their own
They push away physical comfort or don't seem to notice it

questions.text: After a meltdown, can your child talk about what happened?
questions.subtext: Even hours later, once they're fully calm.

options.text: Yes — they can name the feeling and explain what set them off
Partially — they'll say something like "I was mad" but can't explain much more
Not really — they change the subject or say "I don't know"

questions.text: What happens when your child has been sitting still for a long time and then gets frustrated?
questions.subtext: Car rides, waiting rooms, long meals — the pressure cooker moments.

options.text: The frustration is much worse — like the stillness built up pressure they need to release
It's a little worse than usual, but manageable
Doesn't seem to matter — frustration looks the same regardless

questions.text: How does your child respond to changes in sensory environment when upset?
questions.subtext: Dimming lights, turning off music, running cold water on hands, offering a crunchy snack.

options.text: It clearly helps — the shift in sensation resets something
Sometimes it helps, sometimes they don't seem to notice
Sensory changes don't seem to make a difference either way

questions.text: If you narrate what's happening during a meltdown ("You're angry because the tower fell"), how does your child react?
questions.subtext: The classic sportscaster technique — labeling the feeling out loud.

options.text: It visibly helps — they calm down faster when their feelings are named
Mixed results — sometimes it helps, sometimes they yell "STOP TALKING"
It makes things worse or they completely ignore it

questions.text: When your child successfully calms themselves down (rare and beautiful), what did they do?
questions.subtext: Think of a time they pulled out of a spiral on their own.

options.text: Something physical — ran around, jumped, hit a pillow, squeezed their fists
A mix — some movement and some talking or deep breathing
They talked it through, took breaths, or used words to process

questions.text: Does your child have strong preferences about textures, temperatures, or physical sensations in daily life?
questions.subtext: Sock seams, food textures, bath water temperature, clothing tags — the sensory landmines.

options.text: Definitely — they have strong opinions about how things feel on their body
A few preferences, but nothing extreme
Not particularly — they're pretty flexible about sensory stuff

questions.text: How does your child use counting, breathing exercises, or self-talk when they're escalating?
questions.subtext: "Take three deep breaths" / "Count to ten" / "I can handle this."

options.text: They can actually use these tools (at least sometimes) — and it helps
They've tried but it's hit-or-miss — works maybe 30% of the time
These go over their head or they flat-out refuse

high.headline: Body-first regulator
high.detail: Your child processes big feelings through their body first. When emotions spike, their nervous system demands physical output — jumping, stomping, pushing, running. Movement-based strategies will be your most reliable tools.
high.strength: Wall pushups, jumping jacks, stomping walks, pillow punching, and squeezing playdough are natural matches. Build a physical calm-down menu they can grab independently.

medium.headline: Some movement helps
medium.detail: Your child gets partial benefit from physical strategies. Movement alone won't resolve a meltdown, but it can take the edge off enough for other strategies to land.
medium.concern: Pair short movement bursts (10 jumping jacks, wall pushes) with a verbal or sensory follow-up. Movement opens the door — something else walks through it.

low.headline: Movement isn't the key
low.detail: Your child doesn't naturally turn to physical activity when upset. Their nervous system regulates through a different channel. Forcing a run-it-off approach will likely backfire.
low.concern: Skip the "go run around and burn it off" advice. Focus on sensory or verbal tools instead, and add gentle movement (stretching, slow walking) only as a supplement.

high.headline: Sensory-driven soother
high.detail: Your child's nervous system calms through physical sensation — textures, temperatures, pressure, and tactile input. They need to feel something different to feel better.
high.strength: Build a sensory toolkit: weighted blanket, fidget tools, ice cubes to hold, cold water on wrists, crunchy snacks, and textured squeeze balls. Keep options in every room.

medium.headline: Sensory tools work sometimes
medium.detail: Your child responds to sensory input in some situations but not consistently. This is a supporting strategy — useful in the toolkit but not the lead tool.
medium.concern: Experiment with specific inputs to find the ones that click. Cold sensations, deep pressure (bear hugs), and fidgets each hit different pathways. Track what works when.

low.headline: Sensory isn't the path in
low.detail: Your child doesn't naturally calm through tactile or sensory input. They might not notice sensory changes when upset, or the input simply doesn't register as calming.
low.concern: Skip the weighted blanket as a first move. Sensory tools might help for general focus, but during a meltdown, lead with movement or verbal strategies instead.

high.headline: Talks it through
high.detail: Your child processes emotions through language and cognition. Naming feelings, talking through problems, and having their experience validated verbally — these are the strategies that land.
high.strength: Lean into sportscasting ("You're frustrated because..."), feeling wheels, breathing with counting, and structured problem-solving scripts. Their brain calms through understanding.

medium.headline: Words help — after the peak
medium.detail: Verbal strategies work for your child, but timing matters. In the heat of the moment, words can backfire. Once they're halfway down from the peak, talking becomes effective.
medium.concern: Wait until intensity drops below about a 6/10 before introducing verbal strategies. Use a physical or sensory bridge first, then switch to naming and talking.

low.headline: Words don't land yet
low.detail: Your child doesn't regulate through verbal processing right now. Could be developmental, temperamental, or just not their channel. Talking during a meltdown likely makes it worse.
low.concern: Stop trying to reason during the storm. Use physical or sensory strategies to bring intensity down first. Verbal processing can come later — hours later — when the thinking brain is back.

toolkit-strong.headline: Clear Regulation Style
toolkit-strong.subheadline: Your child has strong natural preferences for specific calming strategies, which means you can build a targeted toolkit instead of throwing spaghetti at the wall.
toolkit-strong.explanation: High scores across domains mean your child already shows you what works — through their behavior, not their words. Kids with clear regulation preferences respond faster to the right tools because their nervous system is already wired for that input. Your job is to formalize what's already happening and make those tools accessible before the meltdown hits peak.
nextSteps: Build a portable calm-down kit based on their top-scoring domain — keep one at home, one in the car, one in the school bag
Practice the top strategies during calm moments so they become automatic under stress
Create a visual menu of their top 3-4 strategies they can point to when words aren't available
toolkit-strong.watchOutFor: Strong preferences can become rigid dependencies. Make sure you're building a toolkit with multiple tools, not a crutch with one. If only one strategy works, widen the repertoire gradually.
toolkit-strong.encouragement: You're not starting from scratch — you're organizing what already works. That's a fundamentally different problem than having no tools at all.
toolkit-strong.comparativeContext: Children with clear regulation preferences typically respond to targeted calm-down strategies within 3-5 minutes, compared to 10-15 minutes with generic approaches.

toolkit-building.headline: Toolkit Taking Shape
toolkit-building.subheadline: Your child shows moderate preferences across regulation channels — not locked into one type, which actually gives you room to experiment.
toolkit-building.explanation: Mid-range scores usually mean one of two things: your child uses a mix of strategies inconsistently, or they haven't had enough exposure to find their primary channel yet. Either way, the path forward is structured experimentation. Try specific tools from each domain and track what actually works versus what you wish would work.
nextSteps: Run a two-week experiment: try one strategy from each domain and note which ones your child gravitates toward naturally
Focus on the highest-scoring domain first — that's the strongest signal even if it's not a slam dunk
Introduce calm-down tools during low-stress moments before expecting them to work during a real meltdown
toolkit-building.watchOutFor: Don't confuse "hasn't found it yet" with "nothing works." Kids in this range often need 10-15 exposures to a strategy before it becomes a usable tool. Most parents give up after 2-3 tries.
toolkit-building.encouragement: A mixed profile is actually an advantage — your child has more pathways into calm than a kid who can only use one channel. The work is narrowing down, not building from nothing.
toolkit-building.comparativeContext: Research shows most children need 2-4 weeks of consistent practice with a new regulation strategy before they can use it independently during emotional peaks.

toolkit-starting.headline: Ground Floor
toolkit-starting.subheadline: Your child doesn't show clear regulation preferences yet — which is actually normal, especially for younger kids whose nervous systems are still building these pathways.
toolkit-starting.explanation: Low scores across all domains mean your child's self-regulation system is still under construction. This isn't a failure — it's a developmental stage. Kids under 5 are neurologically incapable of consistent self-regulation, and many older kids simply haven't been taught specific strategies. The biggest mistake here is assuming they should already know how to calm down.
nextSteps: Start with co-regulation — you calm down first, then use your calm to anchor them. Tools come after the foundation.
Introduce ONE strategy from any domain and practice it daily during calm moments for two weeks before evaluating
Focus on reducing meltdown intensity and duration rather than preventing meltdowns entirely
toolkit-starting.watchOutFor: When nothing seems to work, the instinct is to try everything at once. Resist that. One tool, practiced consistently, beats a rotating buffet of strategies your child never learns to use.
toolkit-starting.encouragement: Every regulation strategy your child eventually masters started with a parent modeling it dozens of times while it didn't seem to work. You're at step one, not step zero.
toolkit-starting.comparativeContext: Studies show that co-regulation (parent-led calming) is the primary regulation mechanism for children under 5, and remains important through age 10.
